awd_titl_txt: Inverse Scattering Using Data-Driven Reduced-Order Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Waves are used to image in many applications like radar, ultrasound or geophysical exploration. This project is concerned with developing a novel reduced-order model based methodology for inverse scattering and for imaging of periodic, dispersive structures in nano-photonics. Reduced-order models are extensively used in the dynamical-systems community; however, their use in inverse problems has been limited. The inverse scattering problems in this project are formulated for typical setups, where data are gathered by arrays of sensors that probe an unknown heterogeneous medium with waves and measure the returns. Rather than asking the question "which scattering medium could have caused the measured wave returns" directly, this novel methodology first constructs a reduced-order model from the measured data. The reduced-order model is defined to preserve the physics of wave propagation. The research is motivated by applications in nondestructive evaluation of materials, estimation of sea ice thickness using airborne radar, medical imaging, oil exploration and nano-photonics. Open source software will be provided in the scope of this project
 
This project seeks new directions in inverse scattering and reduced-order modeling. It shows how to view wave propagation as a dynamical system driven by a linear operator that contains information about the medium, modeled by unknown coefficients in the acoustic or electromagnetic wave equation. The dynamical system framework allows the connection to reduced-order modeling techniques, which need to be adapted in order to be useful in inverse scattering. The project pursues this goal for the following specific questions: (1) How can one control waves for improved focusing and subsequent improved imaging, in a pixel scanning fashion? (2) How can one construct and use a ROM for quantitative estimation of the coefficients in the governing wave equations? (3) How can one invert in lossy media? The latter question is connected to an important problem in reduced-order modeling, concerned with the identification of port-Hamiltonian dynamical systems from measurements of their transfer function. This project also seeks to develop model-driven ROMs for dispersive, periodic nano-photonic structures, for speeding up design optimization and parametric inversion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a reduced-order model-based methodology for inverse problems in acoustics and electromagnetics. Such inverse problems are important in applications in medical imaging, non-destructive testing of airplane wings, and radar imaging. Mathematically, inverse scattering seeks to determine coefficients in wave equations like Maxwell?s equations. This is a challenging problem because it is inherently nonlinear and the usual optimization approaches based on least-squares data fit perform poorly due to the rapidly oscillating measured waves and the non-convexity of the objective function.

Recently, a new class of quantitative inversion methods emerge, based on reduced-order models (ROMs). Such methods were developed for the wave-equation in the time-domain and they have been demonstrated to perform better than the commonly used optimization approaches. This project contributed to this new research direction by developing new quantitative inversion methods for the acoustic wave equation and Maxwell?s equation.

Contrary to most approaches in the literature, the reduced-order models developed in this proposal go beyond data-fit and have the following attributes: (1) they inherit the essential features of the PDE; (2) they have a special matrix structure that allows analogies to discretization schemes for the underlying PDE; (3) the entries in the ROM matrix contain spatially localized information about the coefficients of the PDE. These attributes make the ROMs valuable for solving inverse problems. In this project, we developed the following ROM-based methods for imaging and inversion:

(1)    A novel ROM technique to approximate and focus wavefields inside unknown media was developed. Subsequently, this technique was used to formulate a method to recover the unknown medium using the Lippmann-Schwinger equations, which are approximately linearized by the estimates of the wavefields inside the unknown medium.

(2)    A ROM-based method for quantitative inverse scattering based on the minimization of the Frobenius distance between reduced-order models was developed. Classical quantitative inverse scattering methods rely on nonlinear minimization of the data fit and often converge to local minima. Reformulating this objective from data fit to a ROM fit led to a better-behaved objective function. It was shown that this method reconstructs the medium reliably for test cases where classical methods do not.

(3)    A third quantitate inverse scattering method was developed, combining the upper two approaches. Approach (1) uses internal waves to improve data-fit-based inversion methods, approach (2) minimizes the ROM distance and in this third approach, the mismatch of internal solutions is minimized. Together, approaches (1)-(3) outperform classical data-fit-based approaches in terms of reconstructed media for scenes with many scatterers and large extended inclusions of unknown wavespeed. These methods have the potential to impact reconstruction schemes used in ultrasound imaging, exploration geophysics, and nondestructive testing. The next step is to extend them to data setups used in real applications.

(4)    A quantitate imaging algorithm for plane waves in media with absorption was developed. Approaches (1)-(3) are developed for acoustic and electromagnetic waves without absorption. In this approach, we extend the ROM framework to media with absorption for the case of a plane wave incidence. In this case, it is possible to embed the ROM into physical space, that is to interpret the matrix entries of the ROM as finite-difference coefficients of the imaged media.

(5)    A method to efficiently approximate electromagnetic responses of dispersive resonators for applications in nano-photonics. The electromagnetic response of such media is characterized by resonance modes and resonance frequencies. These resonance frequencies are complex, due to absorption and radiation to infinity. The resonance modes diverge away from the resonator making it hard to expand the electromagnetic response directly in these modes. The electromagnetic response was rewritten to only require the resonance modes inside the resonator where they do not diverge, leading to a significant improvement in the number of resonance modes needed to accurately describe the electromagnetic response. This allows the construction of small ROMs that can be used for design optimization of optical resonators.

In the context of this project undergraduate research opportunities were provided. A team of 3 undergraduates worked on the project ``Modes of the infinite string?, which is directly related to one of the research problems. Further, professional development opportunities were provided by co-supervising a PhD student on inverse problems for the anisotropic Maxwell equations.

The results of this research program have been disseminated to the scientific communities of interest by giving talks in university seminars and at international conferences as well as publishing articles. Due to the move of the PI from the USA to Sweden the grant was terminated after 1 year and a little more than half of the project objectives could be achieved.
